content.text: Move the mass to a distance \(d = 70.0 \text{cm}\) from the pivot. Record the distance \(d\) in Table 1.1
Adjust the position of the forcemeter by raising or lowering the clamp until the rule is horizontal and the forcemeter is vertical. Measure and record in the table the reading \(F\) on the forcemeter
Repeat steps (i) and (ii) using \(d\) values of \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(40.0 \text{cm}\), \(30.0 \text{cm}\), \(20.0 \text{cm}\) and \(10.0 \text{cm}\)
Suggest the graph that you could plot to test this idea. You are not asked to plot the graph
against
State the properties of the line that would indicate that \(F\) is directly proportional to \(d\)
A student thinks that \(F\) is directly proportional to \(d\)
A spirit level is a piece of equipment that is placed on a surface to check whether the surface is horizontal
Suggest why a spirit level balanced on the rule is not suitable for checking whether the rule is horizontal in this experiment
Describe briefly how you checked that the rule was horizontal. You may draw a diagram
In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of a load on a rule attached to a force
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. The apparatus has been set up you
The rule is pivoted near one end. Near the other end, the rule is attached to a forcemeter. A mass is hanging from the rule at a distance \(d\) from the pivot
Measure and record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water
Measure the temperature \(\theta\) of the water. Record \(\theta\) in Table 2.1 at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\)
Start the stopclock and record in the table the temperature of the water at 30 s intervals until you have a total of six values up to time \(t = 150 \text{s}\)
Plot a graph of \(\theta /\mathrm{^\circ C}\) ( \(y\) -axis) against \(t / \mathrm{s}\) ( \(x\) -axis)
As you read these words, this experiment is being carried out by candidates in many different countries, using identical apparatus
Suggest two differences in the conditions in the various laboratories that might lead to different graphs
In this experiment, you will investigate the rate of cooling of water
You are provided with a supply of hot water. Carry out the following instructions referring Fig. 2.1
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across the resistors and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. Switch off
Calculate the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the combination of the two resistors arranged in
parallel, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\)
Calculate \(4R_{\mathrm{p}}\)
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across the resistors and the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit. Switch off
Calculate the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\) of the combination of the two resistors at
in series, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\)
\( R_{\mathrm{S}} \)  =
Rearrange the circuit so that the two resistors are connected in series and the voltmeter is connected to measure the potential difference across both resistors
Theory suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = 4R_{\mathrm{p}}\) if the two resistors have the same value
State whether your results indicate that the two resistors have the same value. Justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
Draw a circuit diagram of the new circuit using standard symbols
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across the lamps and the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit. Switch off
Calculate the total resistance \(L_{\mathrm{S}}\) of the combination of the two lamps arranged in series using the equation \(L_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}\)
Using the circuit described in (b), replace the two series resistors with the two lamps
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{4}\) across the lamps at the current \(I_{4}\) in the circuit. Switch off
Calculate the total resistance \(L_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the combination of the two lamps arranged in
parallel using the equation \(L_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{4}}{I_{4}}\)
Calculate \(4L_{\mathrm{p}}\)
Rearrange the circuit to that shown in Fig. 3.1 but with the lamps in place of the re
A student suggests that using lamps instead of resistors changes the conditions of the experiment and that \(4L_{\mathrm{p}}\) will not be equal to \(L_{\mathrm{s}}\) because of a heating effect
From your own observations, state one piece of evidence that supports the student's suggestion that there is a heating effect. You should not do any further calculations
In this experiment, you will investigate resistor combinations in circuits
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper. Draw the outline of the block **ABCD**
Draw a line \(\mathbf{NF}\) to the right of the normal and at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) to the normal as
in Fig. 4.1. \(\mathbf{F}\) is the point where the line meets \(\mathbf{AB}\). Measure and record the length the line \(\mathbf{NF}\)
Extend the line \(\mathbf{NF}\) beyond \(\mathbf{N}\) and place the paper on the pin board
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on the line through \(\mathbf{F}\) and \(\mathbf{N}\), placing one pin close to \(\mathbf{F}\)

Replace the block and observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other

Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), seen through the block, appear one behind the other
Mark the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Remove the block
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label this point \(\mathbf{G}\)
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line \(\mathbf{FH}\)
(j) Calculate the refractive index \(n\) of the material of the block, using the equation \(n = \frac{b}{a}\)
(k) Repeat steps (c) – (j) but with the line from \(\mathbf{N}\) drawn at \(25^{\circ}\) to the left of the normal

b =
n =
Tie your ray trace into this Booklet between pages 10 and 11
Draw the line \(\mathbf{GF}\) and continue it until it meets the normal. Label this point \(\mathbf{H}\)
In this experiment, you will determine the refractive index of the material of a transparent block
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
Fig. 4.1
